description: If \(\left|\begin{array}{cc}2 x & 5 \\ 8 & x\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{cc}6 & -2 \\ 7 & 3\end{array}\right|\), write the value of \(x\)
solution:
Explanation: Given, \(\left|\begin{array}{cc}2 x & 5 \\ 8 & x\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{cc}6 & -2 \\ 7 & 3\end{array}\right|\)
\(\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}-40=18+14\)
\(\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}=72 \Rightarrow x^{2}=36 \Rightarrow x= \pm 6\)

description: Find the cofactor of the element \(a_{23}\) of the determinant \(\left[\begin{array}{lll}5 & 3 & 8 \\ 2 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 3\end{array}\right]\).
If \(A\) is a square matrix of order 3 with \(|A|=9\), then write the value of \(|2 \cdot \operatorname{adj} A|\).
If \(A\) is a \(3 \times 3\) invertible matrix, then what will be the value of \(k\) if \(\operatorname{det}\left(A^{-1}\right)=(\operatorname{det} A)^{k}\) ?
solution:
Explanation:
Given that, \(\operatorname{det}\left(A^{-1}\right)=(\operatorname{det} A)^{k}\)
i.e., \(\left|A^{-1}\right|=|A|^{k}\)
We know that \(\left|A^{-1}\right|=\frac{1}{|A|}=|A|^{-1}\)
\(\therefore \quad k=-1\)

description:
If for any \(2 \times 2\) square matrix \(A\),
\(A(\operatorname{adj} A)=\left[\begin{array}{ll}8 & 0 \\ 0 & 8\end{array}\right]\), then write the value of \(|A|\).
solution:
Explanation:
We have, \(A(\operatorname{adj} A)=\left[\begin{array}{ll}8 & 0 \\ 0 & 8\end{array}\right]\)
\(|A| \cdot \mid=8\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\([\because A(\operatorname{adj} A)=|A| \times I]\)
\(\Rightarrow|A|=8\)

description: In the interval \(\pi / 2<x<\pi\), find the value of \(x\) for which the matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 \sin x & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \sin x\end{array}\right]\) is singular.
solution:
Explanation:
For the matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 \sin x & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \sin x\end{array}\right]\) to be singular, its determinant \(=0\)
\(\therefore\left|\begin{array}{cc}2 \sin x & 3 \\ 1 & 2 \sin x\end{array}\right|=0\)
\(\Rightarrow 4 \sin ^{2} x-3=0 \Rightarrow \sin ^{2} x=\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow \sin x= \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
\(\therefore \quad x=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\left(\because \frac{\pi}{2}<x<\pi\right)\)

description: If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\), find adj \(A\) and verify that \(A(\operatorname{adj} A)=(\operatorname{adj} A) A=|A| I_{3}\).

options.text: Yes, I was able to verify
No, I was not able to verify

solution:
Explanation:
Given, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
Now, \(A_{11}=\cos \alpha, A_{12}=-\sin \alpha, A_{13}=0\),
\(A_{21}=\sin \alpha, A_{22}=\cos \alpha, A_{23}=0\),
\(A_{31}=0, A_{32}=0, A_{33}=1\)
\(\therefore \operatorname{adj}(A)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & 0 \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\(A \cdot \operatorname{adj}(A)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & 0 \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\[=\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\]
\(\operatorname{adj}(A) \cdot A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & 0 \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\[=\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\]
\(|A|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right|\)
\(=\cos \alpha(\cos \alpha-0)+\sin \alpha(\sin \alpha-0)+0=1\)
From (i), (ii) and (iii), we get
\(A(\operatorname{adj} A)=(\operatorname{adj} A) A=|A| I_{3}\).

description:
If \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}3 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -2 & 6\end{array}\right]\), find \(A^{-1}\). Hence, solve the following system of equations:
\(3 x+4 y+2 z=8\)
\(2 y-3 z=3\)
\(x-2 y+6 z=-2\)
solution:
Explanation:
Given, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}3 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -2 & 6\end{array}\right]\)
\(|A|=3(12-6)-4(0+3)+2(0-2)\)
\(=18-12-4=2 \neq 0\)
So, \(A^{-1}\) exists and \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj}(A)\)
Now, \(\operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & -3 & -2 \\ -28 & 16 & 10 \\ -16 & 9 & 6\end{array}\right]^{\prime}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & -28 & -16 \\ -3 & 16 & 9 \\ -2 & 10 & 6\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow A^{-1}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & -28 & -16 \\ -3 & 16 & 9 \\ -2 & 10 & 6\end{array}\right]\)
Given,
\[\begin{aligned}
& 3 x+4 y+2 z=8 \\
& 2 y-3 z=3 \\
& x-2 y+6 z=-2
\end{aligned}\]
Given system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\),
where \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}3 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 \\ 1 & -2 & 6\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]\) and \(B=\left[\begin{array}{c}8 \\ 3 \\ -2\end{array}\right]\)
\(X=A^{-1} B\)
\(=\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}6 & -28 & -16 \\ -3 & 16 & 9 \\ -2 & 10 & 6\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}8 \\ 3 \\ -2\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}48-84+32 \\ -24+48-18 \\ -16+30-12\end{array}\right]\)
\(=\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{c}-4 \\ 6 \\ 2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}-2 \\ 3 \\ 1\end{array}\right]\)
\(\therefore \quad x=-2, y=3, z=1\)

description:
Find the inverse of the matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & -2 & 4\end{array}\right]\). Using the inverse, \(A^{-1}\), solve the system of linear equations
\(x-y+2 z=1 ; 2 y-3 z=1 ; 3 x-2 y+4 z=3\).
solution:
Explanation:
Given \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & -2 & 4\end{array}\right]\)
\(|A|=1(8-6)+1(0+9)+2(0-6)=2+9-12=-1\)
\(\therefore|A| \neq 0\), so \(A^{-1}\) exists
Now, Co-factors are
\[\begin{array}{lll}
A_{11}=2, A_{12}=-9, A_{13}=-6, & A_{21}=0, & A_{22}=-2 \\
A_{23}=-1, A_{31}=-1, A_{32}=3, & A_{33}=2 &
\end{array}\]
Now, \(\operatorname{adj}(A)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & -9 & -6 \\ 0 & -2 & -1 \\ -1 & 3 & 2\end{array}\right]^{\top}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & 0 & -1 \\ -9 & -2 & 3 \\ -6 & -1 & 2\end{array}\right]\)
We know that \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj}(A)\)
\[=-1\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 0 & -1 \\
-9 & -2 & 3 \\
-6 & -1 & 2
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-2 & 0 & 1 \\
9 & 2 & -3 \\
6 & 1 & -2
\end{array}\right]\]
We know that \(A X=B \Rightarrow X=A^{-1} B\) where \(X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 3\end{array}\right]\)
and \(A^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-2 & 0 & 1 \\ 9 & 2 & -3 \\ 6 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-2 & 0 & 1 \\ 9 & 2 & -3 \\ 6 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 3\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}-2+0+3 \\ 9+2-9 \\ 6+1-6\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 2 \\ 1\end{array}\right]\)
Hence \(x=1, y=2\) and \(z=1\)

description:
If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right]\), then find \(A^{-1}\) and use it to solve the following system of the equations :
\(x+2 y-3 z=6,3 x+2 y-2 z=3\),
\(2 x-y+z=2\)
solution:
Explanation:
Given, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\(|A|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right|=1(2-2)-2(3+4)-3(-3-4)\)
\[=-14+21=7 \neq 0\]
\(\therefore \quad A^{-1}\) exists
Now, \(A_{11}=0, A_{12}=-7, A_{13}=-7, A_{21}=1, A_{22}=7\),
\(A_{23}=5, A_{31}=2, A_{32}=-7, A_{33}=-4\)
\(\therefore \quad \operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 2 \\ -7 & 7 & -7 \\ -7 & 5 & -4\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj} A=\frac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 2 \\ -7 & 7 & -7 \\ -7 & 5 & -4\end{array}\right]\)
The given system of equations is
\[\begin{aligned}
& x+2 y-3 z=6 \\
& 3 x+2 y-2 z=3 \\
& 2 x-y+z=2
\end{aligned}\]
The system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\)
where \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 & 1\end{array}\right] ; X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{l}6 \\ 3 \\ 2\end{array}\right]\)
\(\because \quad A^{-1}\) exists, so system of equations has a unique solution given by \(X=A^{-1} B\)
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 2 \\ -7 & 7 & -7 \\ -7 & 5 & -4\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}6 \\ 3 \\ 2\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{c}7 \\ -35 \\ -35\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -5 \\ -5\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow x=1, y=-5, z=-5\)

description:
If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & -3 & 5 \\ 3 & 2 & -4 \\ 1 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right]\), then find \(A^{-1}\). Using \(A^{-1}\), solve the following system of equations :
\(2 x-3 y+5 z=11, 3 x+2 y-4 z=-5\), \(x+y-2 z=-3\)
solution:
Explanation:
We have, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & -3 & 5 \\ 3 & 2 & -4 \\ 1 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow \quad|A|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}2 & -3 & 5 \\ 3 & 2 & -4 \\ 1 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right|\)
\[
\begin{aligned}
& =2(-4+4)+3(-6+4)+5(3-2) \\
& =-6+5=-1 \neq 0
\end{aligned}
\]
\(\therefore \quad A^{-1}\) exists.
Now, \(A_{11}=0, A_{12}=2, A_{13}=1, A_{21}=-1, A_{22}=-9\),
\[
A_{23}=-5, A_{31}=2, A_{32}=23, A_{33}=13
\]
\(\therefore \quad \operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -1 & 2 \\ 2 & -9 & 23 \\ 1 & -5 & 13\end{array}\right]\)
Now, \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj} A=(-1)\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -1 & 2 \\ 2 & -9 & 23 \\ 1 & -5 & 13\end{array}\right]\)
\[
=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & -2 \\
-2 & 9 & -23 \\
-1 & 5 & -13
\end{array}\right]
\]
The given system of equations is
\(2 x-3 y+5 z=11,3 x+2 y-4 z=-5, x+y-2 z=-3\)
The system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\),
where \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & -3 & 5 \\ 3 & 2 & -4 \\ 1 & 1 & -2\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{c}11 \\ -5 \\ -3\end{array}\right]\)
Since \(A^{-1}\) exists, therefore, system of equations has a unique solution given by
\[
\begin{aligned}
X & =A^{-1} B=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & -2 \\
-2 & 9 & -23 \\
-1 & 5 & -13
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
11 \\
-5 \\
-3
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
2 \\
3
\end{array}\right] \\
\Rightarrow \quad & x=1, y=2 \text { and } z=3 .
\end{aligned}
\]

description:
If \(\left[\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right]\), find \(A^{-1}\). Using \(A^{-1}\), solve the system of equations
\[\begin{aligned}
& y+2 z=5 \\
& x+2 y+3 z=10 \\
& 3 x+y+z=9
\end{aligned}\]
solution:
Explanation:
Given, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow|A|=\left[\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right]=0(2-3)-1(1-9)+2(1-6)\)
\(=8-10=-2\)
As \(|A| \neq 0 . \therefore A^{-1}\) exists and \(A^{-1}\) is given by \(\frac{1}{|A|}(\operatorname{adj} A)\)
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 8 & -5 \\
1 & -6 & 3 \\
-1 & 2 & -1
\end{array}\right]^{\prime}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 1 & -1 \\
8 & -6 & 2 \\
-5 & 3 & -1
\end{array}\right] \\
& \therefore A^{-1}=-\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 1 & -1 \\
8 & -6 & 2 \\
-5 & 3 & -1
\end{array}\right]
\end{aligned}
\]
Given,
\[
\begin{aligned}
& y+2 z=5 \\
& x+2 y+3 z=10 \\
& 3 x+y+z=9
\end{aligned}
\]
The given system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\)
Where, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]\) and \(B=\left[\begin{array}{c}5 \\ 10 \\ 9\end{array}\right]\)
\(X=A^{-1} B\)
by using equation (i), we get
\[
\begin{aligned}
& X=\frac{-1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & 1 & -1 \\
8 & -6 & 2 \\
-5 & 3 & -1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
5 \\
10 \\
9
\end{array}\right] \Rightarrow \frac{-1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{l}
-5+10-9 \\
40-60+18 \\
-25+30-9
\end{array}\right]=\frac{-1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{l}
-4 \\
-2 \\
-4
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}
2 \\
1 \\
2
\end{array}\right] \\
& \therefore \quad x=2, y=1, z=2
\end{aligned}
\]

description:
If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{lll}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right]\), find \(A^{-1}\). Hence, solve the system of equations
\( x+y+z=6, x+2 z=7,3 x+y+z=12 \)
solution:
Explanation:
We have \(A=\left[\begin{array}{lll}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 & 1\end{array}\right]\)
Now, \(|A|=1(0-2)-1(1-6)+1(1)\)
\[
=-2+5+1=4 \neq 0
\]
\(\therefore \quad A^{-1}\) exists.
Now, \(A_{11}=-2, A_{12}=5, A_{13}=1, A_{21}=0, A_{22}=-2, A_{23}=2, A_{31}\)
\(=2, A_{32}=-1, A_{33}=-1\)
\(\therefore \operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-2 & 0 & 2 \\ 5 & -2 & -1 \\ 1 & 2 & -1\end{array}\right]\)
\(\therefore A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj} A=\frac{1}{4}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-2 & 0 & 2 \\ 5 & -2 & -1 \\ 1 & 2 & -1\end{array}\right]\)
Now the given equations are
\[
\begin{aligned}
& x+y+z=6 \\
& x+0 y+2 z=7 \\
& 3 x+y+z=12
\end{aligned}
\]
The given system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\) where
\[
A=\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 2 \\
3 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{c}
6 \\
7 \\
12
\end{array}\right]
\]
\(\because \quad A^{-1}\) exists, so system has a unique solution given by \(X=A^{-1} B\).
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{4}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-2 & 0 & 2 \\ 5 & -2 & -1 \\ 1 & 2 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}6 \\ 7 \\ 12\end{array}\right]\)
\(=\frac{1}{4}\left[\begin{array}{c}-12+0+24 \\ 30-14-12 \\ 6+14-12\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{4}\left[\begin{array}{c}12 \\ 4 \\ 8\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 1 \\ 2\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow \quad x=3, y=1, z=2\)

description:
Determine the product
\[
\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-4 & 4 & 4 \\
-7 & 1 & 3 \\
5 & -3 & -1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -1 & 1 \\
1 & -2 & -2 \\
2 & 1 & 3
\end{array}\right] \text { and use it to solve the }
\]
system of equations \(x-y+z=4\), \(x-2 y-2 z=9,2 x+y+3 z=1\).
solution:
Explanation:
We have, \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3\end{array}\right]\)
\(=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-4+4+8 & 4-8+4 & -4-8+12 \\ -7+1+6 & 7-2+3 & -7-2+9 \\ 5-3-2 & -5+6-1 & 5+6-3\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{lll}8 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 8 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 8\end{array}\right]=81\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3\end{array}\right]=\) I
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3\end{array}\right]^{-1}=\frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-4 & 4 & 4 \\ -7 & 1 & 3 \\ 5 & -3 & -1\end{array}\right]\)
The given system of equation is
\(x-y+z=4, x-2 y-2 z=9,2 x+y+3 z=1\) and it can be written as \(A X=B\), where
\[
A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -1 & 1 \\
1 & -2 & -2 \\
2 & 1 & 3
\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array}\right] \text { and } B=\left[\begin{array}{l}
4 \\
9 \\
1
\end{array}\right]
\]
Here, \(|A|=1(-6+2)+1(3+4)+1(1+4)\)
\[
=-4+7+5=8 \neq 0
\]
So, the given system of equations has a unique solution given by \(X=A^{-1} B\).
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
-4 & 4 & 4 \\
-7 & 1 & 3 \\
5 & -3 & -1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}
4 \\
9 \\
1
\end{array}\right]=\frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{c}
-16+36+4 \\
-28+9+3 \\
20-27-1
\end{array}\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{c}
24 \\
-16 \\
-8
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
-2 \\
-1
\end{array}\right] \Rightarrow x=3, y=-2, z=-1
\end{aligned}
\]

description: A total amount of Rs 7,000 is deposited in three different savings bank accounts with annual interest rates of \(5 \%, 8 \%\) and \(8 \frac{1}{2} \%\) respectively. The total annual interest from these three accounts is Rs 550 . Equal amounts have been deposited in the \(5 \%\) and \(8 \%\) savings accounts. Find the amount deposited in each of the three accounts, with the help of matrices.
solution:
Explanation:
Let \(Rs. x\), \(Rs. y\) and \(Rs. z\) be deposited at the rates of interest \(5 \%, 8 \%\) and \(8 \frac{1}{2} \%\) respectively.
According to question,
\(x+y+z=7000\)
\(x-y=0\)
\(x \cdot \frac{5}{100}+y \cdot \frac{8}{100}+z \cdot \frac{17}{2} \times \frac{1}{100}=550\)
\(\Rightarrow 10 x+16 y+17 z=110000\)
The system of equations can be written as \(A X=B\)
where, \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 \\ 10 & 16 & 17\end{array}\right], X=\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]\) and \(B=\left[\begin{array}{c}7000 \\ 0 \\ 110000\end{array}\right]\)
\(|A|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 \\ 10 & 16 & 17\end{array}\right|=1(-17)-(17)+1(16+10)=-8 \neq 0\)
\(\therefore \quad A^{-1}\) exists. So, system of equations has a unique solution and it is given by \(X=A^{-1} B\)
Now, \(A_{11}=-17, A_{12}=-17, A_{13}=26\),
\(A_{21}=-1, A_{22}=7, A_{23}=-6\),
\(A_{31}=1, A_{32}=1, A_{33}=-2\)
\(\therefore \quad \operatorname{adj} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-17 & -1 & 1 \\ -17 & 7 & 1 \\ 26 & -6 & -2\end{array}\right]\)
and \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|} \operatorname{adj} A=\frac{1}{-8}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-17 & -1 & 1 \\ -17 & 7 & 1 \\ 26 & -6 & -2\end{array}\right]\)
Now, \(X=A^{-1} B\)
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]=-\frac{1}{8}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}-17 & -1 & 1 \\ -17 & 7 & 1 \\ 26 & -6 & -2\end{array}\right] \cdot\left[\begin{array}{c}7000 \\ 0 \\ 110000\end{array}\right]\)
\(\operatorname{adj}(A)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}4 & 0 & 0 \\ -4 & 4 & 0 \\ 0 & -4 & 4\end{array}\right]\)
\(\Rightarrow x=1125=y, z=4750\)
